title: chat.asc.upenn.edu ver comparison
text:
I realized I am the only PhD student in this class. That motivated me to dive deeper into my PhD program at Annenberg. I tried two versions of chat.asc.upenn.edu, which I discovered after attending Professor Matt‚Äôs AI workshop a couple of days ago. The workshop was amazing, so I thought‚Äîwhy not do a little exploration of what I learned! I asked it what the good things are about the Annenberg PhD program. Let‚Äôs see what it gives. Also, I wasn‚Äôt familiar with the Haiku version‚Äîthe name gives off more poetic vibes, so I wanted to explore whether that‚Äôs true or not. We shall see.


Prompt Generation onchat.asc.upenn.edu 3.5-haiku vs.¬†gpt4o
1st, 2nd, 3rd tiral with the same prompt of: what is good thing about upenn annenberg phd
  


üìä Comparison: Claude 3.5 vs GPT-4o








Aspect
Claude 3.5-haiku
GPT-4o




Style & Format
Bullet-point lists with numbered categories and sub-bullets.
Narrative paragraphs with bolded section headers.


Tone
Factual, outline-like, efficient.
Persuasive, descriptive, brochure-like.


1st trial
Reputation, research opportunities, faculty, funding, networking, interdisciplinarity, location.
Interdisciplinary approach, renowned faculty, research, professional development, community/collaboration.


2nd trial
Adds career outcomes (tenure-track, alumni network), critical & innovative thinking, and media/tech focus.
Adds cultural context (Philadelphia‚Äôs diversity), collegial environment, professional development, broader academic focus areas.


3rd trial
Strong on funding competitiveness, diverse faculty, interdisciplinary flexibility, professional networks.
Highlights impactful research early, strong funding support, networking, and collaborative community.


Strengths
Broad coverage of practical factors (funding, alumni, career prospects).
Rich detail on student experience, academic culture, and research environment.


Overall Feel
Fact sheet ‚Äì compact, informative, career-oriented.
Brochure ‚Äì polished, engaging, student-experience focused.





How to Decide Which to Use

If you need efficiency, structure, or raw ideas üëâ Claude 3.5
If you need polish, flow, or persuasive storytelling üëâ GPT-4o
Sometimes, the best workflow is hybrid! Start with Claude 3.5 to get a structured draft/outline. Feed that into GPT-4o to turn it into a polished narrative.



‚ú® Insight for Your Future Tasks
Since I am a PhD student, I‚Äôll face a mix of analytical tasks and communicative tasks.

For research synthesis, brainstorming frameworks, and organizing literature, Claude‚Äôs style will save my time.
For grant writing, papers, teaching materials, or public-facing work, GPT-4o‚Äôs fluency will help you connect with my audience.

üëâ You might think of them like two tools in your research toolbox:

Claude = bullet-pointed notebook üìù
GPT-4o = polished essay draft üìñ

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: About
